I pulled out a sovereign, and said, "Here is my money, where is your watch?" he snatched the sovereign from me, threw the chain at me, and ran off - I followed him, but two women who were there stopped me; I got from them, and White stopped the prisoner without my losing sight of him - he then said, "Here is your sovereign; say no more about it" - White would not let me do so.

Prisoner. Q. What time was it? A. About two o'clock- I gave him the sovereign about four; I saw no watch - I had money, although I said I had none - I said nothing about my mate - I did not tell him to wait for me - the chain and seals are only gilt - I did not ask a gentleman if they were gold - he would follow me - I could not get rid of him.

ROBERT JAMES WHITE
. I was in East-street, Commercial-road. I had seen the prisoner talking with the prosecutor at the end of the street - they then walked up the street, and I saw two women following them; I was standing near the top - the prisoner and prosecutor turned back, stopped about the middle of the street, and talked - the prisoner then ran up the street, and two women took hold of the prosecutor; I ran, and secured the prisoner till the prosecutor came up - he then said, "Here is the sovereign, take it, and settle it;" I took him to the watch-house.
Prisoner. Q. Did you ever see me before? A. No - I suspected you by the girls who were with you; I was about ten yards off - I did not see you receive the sovereign - I saw it when I took you.

JOHN LEMING
. I am an officer. I received him in charge, and found a sovereign on one of the women - the prosecutor said if the prisoner would give him the sovereign, he would let him go; I searched the prisoner, and found no sovereign on him.

GEORGE FLEMING
. I saw him pass the sovereign to one of the women as we went along - she was one of the women who had stopped me; I saw it found on another woman, but not the one he had passed it to.
Prisoner. Q. Will you swear to the sovereign? A. Yes.

Prisoner's Defence. Gentlemen, can you believe such a man - he says he can swear to the sovereign - if I had robbed him, would I have given him the goods - the truthis, I had just come from Bristol; I met a man, who sold me these things for 18s., and, having no money, I sold them to this man.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1986.
WILLIAM COTMAN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 31st of August , 1 seal, value 2s., and 1 watch-key, value 1s. the goods of
Thomas Molloy
, from his person .

THOMAS MOLLOY. I am a pilot , and live in the trinityalm's-houses, Mile-end. On the 31st of August, about the middle of the day, I was walking behind Bonner's houses, Bethnal-green
, being ill; two men suddenly rushed upon me, one on each side - the one on the right snatched at my watch - the ribbon broke, and he got the seal and key; I do not know them - they were gone in an instant - I have not found the property.
Cross-examined by MR. BARRY. Q. Have you ever said that five or six persons were near you? A. I only saw these two - they came as if from a corner - it happened in a field.

JAMES PURSER
. I was in Bonner's-fields, between eleven and twelve o'clock that morning - I saw the prisoner there, and five others, crossing the field on the north of Bethnalgreen; I saw them changing their clothes - the prisoner and two others ran round a building to meet the prosecutor, who was walking there; I met an officer, and told him - he went home and got his staff; I had seen the prisoner before - he is a tripe-man, and lives in Brick-lane - after he had committed the robbery (as I suppose) I saw them all run to the brick-kiln.

GEORGE HALL
. I was at the Greyhound, Bethal-green, on the 31st of August; I saw the prisoner, and watched him across the fields; I saw him and three others pull off their clothes, and change them; I then saw them go round the house, as if to meet the prosecutor; I followed, and heard a cry of Stop thief! I saw them all run to the back of a brick-kiln, and there they exchanged clothes again - one man pulled off a pepper and salt jacket, and gave it to the prisoner; the prosecutor was not two minutes out of my sight.
Cross-examined. Q. How long after they passed the Greybound did you see them change their clothes? A. It might be ten minutes; I am sure of the prisoner; I have known him some time.

RICHARD COLLEY
. I saw the prosecutor in the field, as I was going out of my yard; I saw three men following me - when I got farther, I saw them before me - one of them had a pepper and salt dress; I cannot say that was the prisoner, but I saw that man make a push at the prosecutor's fob, and then heard a cry of Stop thief!
Cross-examined. Q. You saw a man in a grey jacket make a push? A. Yes - the prosecutor is near-sighted, and had a shade on his eye; I saw nobody in a blue or green jacket.

COURT. Q. How far were the other two from the man who made the attack? A. Only a few yards - they ran by me together; I saw them together afterwards - one said to the other, "Come along, come along;" I do not know them.
The prisoner received a good character.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Transported for Seven Years .

1987.
MARY ANN JOHNSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 22d of September , 1 watch, value 2l.; 1 chain, value 1l.; 2 seals, value 20s., and 2 keys, value 20s., the goods of
Thomas Gowland
, from his person .

THOMAS GOWLAND. I am master of a ship . On the 22d of September I met the prisoner between twelve and one o'clock at night - I treated her at a public-house, and when we came out she snatched out my watch - I called Stop thief! the watchman ran, took her, and found the watch on her - one of the seals are gone.
Prisoner. Q. Did not you go home with me? A. No - I did not give her the watch to keep till next day; I gave her no money.

THOMAS BOYCE
. I am a watchman. On the 22d of September I saw the prisoner running; I came up, and asked why she ran; she said she wanted to get into the highway; Gowland was with another watchman - he said he was robbed; I pursued, and took the prisoner in King David-lane, with the watch in her bosom. Gowland had been drinking, but was sober; the prisoner said he gave her the watch - he decied it.

THOMAS DEVERELL
. I was constable of the night. - The prisoner was brought to the watch-house - she said Gowland gave her the watch in a house where they had been - he was not quite sober - he had only a shilling about him.

THOMAS GOWLAND
. I suppose it was in a public-house that I treated her, but I do not know. I think I gave it her at the bar, but I do not recollect; I cannot say whether any other person was there. We were not alone in a room; I did not go to her apartment.
Prisoner's Defence. He was in my room, and gave me the watch.

ELIZABETH BURTON
. I live at No. 41, Philip-street, St. George's. Between twelve and one o'clock the prosecutor brought the prisoner home to a house I lodge in - I am sure of it; she called me down, and he gave me a shilling to fetch liquor; I fetched some rum, and brought 7d. back; the prisoner said he had asked her to go on board ship with him - I persuaded her not, but she said she should: I went to bed, and shut her door; in about half an hour she called me, and said she was going - I heard no more.

SARAH ROUTLEDGE
. I keep this house. I heard the prisoner come in with somebody, but did not see them.
NOT GUILTY .

1988.
ELIZABETH SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of October , 2 shirts, value 10s.; 1 table-cloth, value 1s.; 1 night-cap, value 6d.; 1 bed-gown, value 3d.; 1 pair of stockings, value 6d.; 1 petticoat, value 6d.; 1 pair of gloves, value 3d.; 1 cravat, value 2s.; 1 cap, value 6d., and 1 handkerchief, value 3d., the goods of
Ann Dales
, widow , from her person .

ANN DALES. I am a widow, and live in Thomas-street, Brick-lane. On the 18th of October I was in Brick-lane
, with these articles in a bundle; I went into the Crown public-house, and got a glass of gin - I came out again, and in a minute I was knocked down by a blow on the head, from a woman, and my bundle taken from me; I screamed out "I am robbed," and begged them to return it, as they did not belong to me. I received it fromtwo men in lest than two minutes. The prisoner is quite a stranger.

THOMAS FOWLES
. On the evening of the 18th of October I was at the corner of Slater-street, Brick-lane, and saw the prosecutrix with her bonnet torn, and a mob round her; she then had the bundle in her hand; the prisoner was there, and said she was her aunt; I brought her to the light, and the prosecutrix said she was no relation.

ROBERT GARRATT
. I was at the corner of Slater-street, saw a mob, and went up - the prosecutrix said,"For God's sake, give me the things - I am robbed;" the prisoner was there, and kept calling her aunt and mother - the prisoner then had the bundle, and was going away; I snatched it from her, and gave it to the prosecutrix.

FREDERICK OSMAN PRESTED
. I saw this disturbance. I saw the prisoner and the prosecutrix just after they came out of the public-house - the prisoner then had the bundle, and said, "Come along aunt;" she seemed to be going on; the bundle was taken from her - she then flew at the prosecutrix, and tore her bonnet.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was in the public-house - we came out together, and get into a few words; I was rather intoxicated, and she said I had robbed her.
GUILTY . Aged 35.
Transported for Seven Years .

1989.
ELIZABETH THORNTON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of October , 1 watch, value 1l.; 1 seal, value 5s.; 1 chain, value 1s.; 2 keys, value 1s.; 1 crown-piece, 11 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the property of
Charles Boyle
, from his person .

CHARLES BOYLE. I live in Paddington-street. On the 18th of October I met the prisoner, and went to a house with her; she took my watch out of my pocket; I missed it soon after, and made her give it back - I then put it into my pocket, and when I went to bed I put it under my pillow, in my pocket - it had two keys and a seal to it - I had 16s. 6d. in my pocket; there were two other women in the room; I was awoke in the morning, by her pulling my trousers from under my head - she handed something out of the pocket to another girl, but I did not see what; the other girl ran down stairs - she was dressed, but the prisoner was not; I took hold of my trousers, and missed the watch and money; I heard it rattle in her hand - I am sure I had it when I went there - I was not very sober.

HENRY RICHARD BUCKERIDGE
. I live near the prisoner; Boyle called and said he had been robbed - I went and searched the prisoner, but found nothing; there was another woman in the room, but I cannot find the woman who had the money.
Prisoner's Defence. The woman who took the money I do not know - I never had his trousers in my hand.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Transported for Seven Years .

1990.
MARIA SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 17th of September , 1 ring, value 3s., the goods of
Jane Woolf
, from her person .

JANE WOOLF. I lived in Satchwell's-rents, Bethnalgreen. On the 17th of September I was going through Chequer-alley
with Pitt and met the prisoner and another woman - they first began knocking Pitt about - they knocked him down - the prisoner then came, and struck me - took the ring off my finger, and twisted my arm - I I told her I would not go without the ring - she went away, and denied having it.

WILLIAM PITT
. I was with Woolf in Chequer-alley. The prisoner stopped me, and struck me - I did not see her do any thing to Woolf; but after she abused me, and I got away - Woolf said she had lost a berring, and would not go without it.

JOHN McDONALD
. I came up, and found Pitt all in a gore of blood - I saw the prisoner with Woolf - the prisoner said she would charge her nothing to go up to her room - I had seen her take the ring from Woolf, and I took hold of her - she denied having it - I found it in her hand, and gave it to Brown.

JOHN BROWN
. I am the watch-house-keeper. I have the ring.

JAMES FORDHAM
. I saw a riot in Chequer-alley - went up, and saw the prisoner fighting with two other women - I went with an officer, and dispersed the mob - when I returned, my brother-officer said the woman had lost her ring, and I took her.

THOMAS HARRISON
. I took the prisoner to the watch-house - she said if she had not been drunk, there was plenty of time to have got away - the prosecutrix and Pitt had been drinking - I found the prisoner in a house, and was obliged to force the door to get her.
Prisoner's Defence. Pitt was ill-using Woolf - I went to assist her, and the ring came off; I wished to have given it her; but McDonald came and took it from me.
NOT GUILTY .

1991.
MARY ANN LEWIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 24th of September , 1 crown-piece, 3 half-crowns, 2 shillings, and 1 sixpence, the monies of
Jacob Evanson
, from his person .

JACOB EYANSON. I am a sailor , and work in the West India-docks. On Sunday morning, the 24th of September, at four o'clock, I was going home, met the prisoner, and went with her to a house in Wentworth-street
- I took out a green flannel purse from my trousers, with 16s. in it, and gave her one - I never saw her before: I returned my purse to my right-hand trousers pocket; I found she was rubbing me down: I told her to be quiet; she turned round, and gave three knocks at the door; another young woman came up, and asked me to pay for the room; I said I had paid for it; the prisoner then absconded; I felt my pocket, and said I was robbed; I went down, found two watchmen, and told them I was robbed; one of them searched the house, but could not find her; I was sober; the money was found on her at the watch-house soon after; but I had no marks on it.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Are you married? A. Yes: I have three children; my wife was in the country; the prisoner left me about half-past four o'clock, and was taken before five - I was about ten minutes with her - I knew her face - there was a candle in the room; I never said I thought her to be the girl; I had a pint of beer with her mother at a public-house, by Hicks's-hall; and she paid for it.

WILLIAM HEATH
. I am a watchman of Whitechapel. I heard a cry of Watch! before five o'clock on this morning, and saw the prosecutor, who said he had been robbed bya woman in black, of one crown, three half-crowns, a sixpence, and two shillings; I waited while another watchman went into the house, but could not find her; we found the prisoner in Osborne-street - the prosecutor said she was the woman; she said she never saw him in her life; I asked what money she had; she said she did not know; I then searched her, and found three half-crowns, a sixpence, six shillings, and 1s. 3d. in copper; but no green bag.
Cross-examined. Q. Were there any crown-pieces? A. No; 15d. was in copper; he only described her as a woman in black.

SAMUEL SMITH
. I keep the Two Brewers public-house - the prisoner came there on this morning; one or two men were there, but not the prosecutor; they had two glasses of liquor, which came to 8d.; the prisoner gave me a crown-piece; I gave her in charge.
Cross-examined. Q. Did you give her 15d. in copper? A. No.
Prisoner's Defence. I never saw the man.
GUILTY . Aged 20.
Transported for Seven Years .

1992.
HARRIET DOREE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 15th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 5s., the goods of
John Lester
, from his person .

JOHN LESTER. I am a sailor , and live in Ratcliff-highway. On the 15th of October I was in a public-house drinking with some shipmates, and missed my handkerchief off my neck, and found an old one in the room of it; I took the prisoner in the house, suspecting her, and the officer found it on her - I had said nothing to her; I was intoxicated.

THOMAS OBORN
. I am an officer. The prisoner was brought to the watch-house, about four o'clock in the afternoon; the prosecutor charged her with taking the handkerchief off his neck: I asked her where it was; she pulled out an old one, and said she had no other; when I said I would search her, she gave me another from her pocket.
Prisoner's Defence. He was in liquor, and gave it me to pawn, as he had no money; I lent him the old one.
NOT GUILTY .

1993.
ELIZA WILSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 18th of October , 1 gown, value 1s. 6d., and 2 yards of cotton, value 18d. , the goods of
Robert Dowzall
.

LOUISA DOWZALL
. I am the wife of Robert Dowzall; we lodge in Queen-street, Seven Dials, the prisoner is a stranger. I saw her going out of my room, on the 18th of October - I followed, and caught her a few yards off with my gown, and this cotton, under my arm; I asked how she came to take them; she said she had not been there.(Property produced and sworn to.)

THOMAS FOXHALL
. I am an officer. I took charge of her.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .

1994.
JOHN SAUNDERS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 5th of October , 3 sheets, value 13s.; 1 towel, value 1s., and 2 handkerchiefs, value 1s. , the goods of
James Hall
.

JAMES HALL. I keep the King's Head public-house, at Hampstead
. On the 5th of October the prisoner hired a bed, and paid me at the bar - he left next morning at a quarter to seven o'clock - my wife sent the girl up-stairs, and the sheets and other property were gone.

ELIZABETH DENNIS
. I am in the prosecutor's service. The prisoner slept in a double-bedded room; I heard him go down-stairs next morning, and saw him go out; I thought he looked rather bulky; I ran up-stairs, and missed two sheets off the other bed - not the one he slept in, and two handkerchiefs; he had broken open the door of an opposite room, and taken a towel.

JOHN BUSTIN
. I received the prisoner in charge, in the house, on the morning of the 5th of October - I asked what he had got about him; I found two sheets in his small clothes, with the towel and handkerchiefs; I said,"Is that all?" he took off his hat, and said, "There is another sheet;" I took him to the watch-house, and found these chisels and a phosphorus box in his pocket.(Property produced and sworn to.)
The prisoner pleaded poverty.
GUILTY . Aged 24.
Transported Seven Years .

1995.
ABRAHAM SPRADBURY
was indicted for
stealing, on the 20th of September , 1 coat, value 10s. , the goods of
William Houseman
.

WILLIAM HOUSEMAN. On the 20th of September this coat was in my chaise-cart, in Union-street, Spitalfields
; I was away from it half-an-hour, and on returning missed it.(Property produced and sworn to.)

THOMAS NEWMAN
. I am a scale-maker, and live in Spital-fields; I saw the prisoner go up to this cart, take hold of the coat, and run off; I called Stop thief! - he threw it down - an officer took it up - another officer took - I am sure he is the man.

JOSEPH ADAMS
. I heard a cry, saw the coat thrown down, and took it up.

JAMES BROWN
. I am an officer. I stopped the prisoner; I did not see the coat thrown down - he was running very fast, came against me with violence, and fell down.
Prisoner's Defence. I was going towards Bishopsgate - I was running at the head of some people, and was stopped.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

1996.
WILLIAM RIPPIN
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of September , 4 carpenter's planes, value 14s., the goods of
George Ewins
, and 1 plane, value 3s. , the goods of
John Davis
.

GEORGE EWINS. I am a carpenter , and work for John Davis. On the 26th of September I was working with him in John's-place; I left these tools safe on the night of the 25th, behind some oak sills in a corner, and in the morning they were gone; I had seen the prisoner about the buildings about a week before.(Property produced and sworn to.)

JAMES BUCK
. I am a constable. On the morning of the 26th of September I was in Bethual green-road, and saw the prisoner with another personer sitting on a bankfacing the Dundee Arms public-house - the prisoner had four planes in an apron, and the other had one; I asked the prisoner who they belonged to - he said to himself, and he was going to pawn them, and was waiting for the pawnbroker's shop to he open; I took him to Worship-street; he was detained for a week, and the owner not being found, was liberated; I afterwards found the prosecutors.

PHILIP PARISH
. I apprehended the prisoner.
Prisoner's Defence. I did not say they were mine, but that a young man gave me them to mind.
JAMES BUCK re-examined. He said that at the watch-house; but at first he said they were his, and it was hard to take a man for his own property.
GUILTY . Aged 23.
Confined Three Months .

1997.
MARIA COUTTS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 1 carpet, value 13s.; 1 pair of boots, value 10s., and 3 bed valances, value 5s. , the goods of
Samuel Eyland
.

SAMUEL EYLAND. I am a shoemaker , and live in Hanway-yard
. I heard a cry of Stop thief! about three o'clock, on the 29th of September - I ran out, and saw my servant picking up these articles, which are mine; I went with her to the bottom of the street, and took the prisoner, whom she pointed out.

JEMIMA WARD
. I am Mr. Eyland's servant. I was coming out of the room, and saw the prisoner coming down-stairs with a bundle - she was a stranger; I followed, calling Stop thief! - she dropped it about ten yards off; I took it up - it contained these articles, which are master's; I am certain of her person.

JOHN WOODWARD
. I took her in charge.
The prisoner pleaded distress.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .

1998.
MARY DAVIS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 3d of October , 1 blanket, value 4s. , the goods of
Ann Tarlizzic
, widow .

ANN TARLIZZIC. I am a widow, and live in Golden-lane
. The prisoner is a stranger; on the 3d of October I found this blanket on the landing-place - she had been up-stairs, and taken it from a room, which was not occupied.

ROBERT TIPPETT
. I am the prosecutrix's grandson; I saw the prisoner sitting on the landing-place, on this blanket; she asked me for some person whom I did not know: I made no answer, and went into a back-room, and shortly after she asked how long the person who lodged in the front room would be; I said, "I could not tell;" she shut the door - I heard her go down soon after; I looked after her, and saw this blanket fall from her on the landing-place; I asked her what business she had to take it - she said she had not taken it, that she kicked it on the stairs, but I had seen her sitting on it; an officer was fetched, and took her.

SARAH GABLE
. I lodge in the house; I heard a noise, opened the door, and Tippett said, "This woman has taken a blanket."

JOHN TWEEDY
. I am an officer. I took her in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I was not in any room - I went on an errand to a man's wife there; it laid on the bannisters and as I turned round, it fell down.
GUILTY . Aged 34.
Transported for Seven Years .
FOURTH DAY. MONDAY, OCTOBER 30.
Fourth Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

1998.
JOHN SMITH
was indicted for
stealing, on the 12th of October , 1 watch, value 6l.; 1 watch-key, value 4s.; 2 seals, value 6d.; 3 sovereigns; 1 half-crown; 14 shillings; and 1s. sixpence, the property of William Mann; 1 watch, value 1l.; 2 seals, value 10s.; 1 watch-key, value 4s., and 1 watch-chain, value 6d. , the goods of
Richard Bowden
.

RICHARD BOWDEN. I am an officer of the Customs . I was on board the Atalanta on the 12th of October; she was lying off Irongate, St. Catherine's
, near the Tower - I was awoke by a person taking my watch from off a locker, near to where I was lying - I had put it there the night before - I got out of bed, and saw a person going up the companion-ladder - I followed, saw him go to the adjoining vessel, and called Stop thief! I did not overtake him, but when I got to that vessel, I found my watch in one place and the case in another, on the deck - I saw the prisoner in about a minute in custody.

WILLIAM MANN
. I am master of the Atalanta. Bowden slept on board that night - I heard an alarm, and saw him find his watch and case - I also missed a watch, three sovereigns, and some silver, from the state-room; I went and found the prisoner in a boat alone in about five minutes, and charged him with it - he denied having been on board, but said, he was smuggling two bottles of gin, and was pursued by the police; that he belonged to a vessel in the tier above; he was without a hat - a person brought it to him, and he owned it - as I was going down into the boat where he was, somebody said, "Captain, he has hove your watch overboard;" he said the man was a liar.

JOSEPH HARDING
. On the morning of the 12 of October, I took the prisoner in this boat, about four vessels from the Atalanta - he said he went there to sleep, and that he had been let out of prison the night before - I found 1s. 4d. on him.

THOMAS HAMMOND
. I am a Custom-house officer, and was on board the next vessel to the Atalanta - I heard an alarm, went on deck, and saw Bowden pick up his watch; I saw a person getting into the next vessel and followed him four or five vessels off into a boat - some men in the sixth vessel called out, "He is in a boat" - I got down and callared him; it was the prisoner - he put his hand into his pocket and took out something - then put his hand into the water and dropped it - I cannot tell what it was - he said he was pursued by two officers, as he had had two bottles of gin, and lost his hat in the scuffle - I said that was a lame story, and it was likely he had taken the watch - he said I was a d - d liar - I then went and found his hat near the companion door of the Atalanta - I brought it to him, put it on, and it fitted him very well; I said, "I have brought your hat;" he said, "Oh! have you;" I believehim to be the man whom I saw crossing the ships - it was between two and three o'clock in the morning.(Property produced and sworn to.)

Prisoner's Defence. A countryman promised me two bottles of gin - I went on board to get it - I was pursued by an officer, and escaped across the tier, and in a quarter of an hour, they came and said I had robbed them - my hat had fallen into the water.
GUILTY . Aged 26.
Transported for Seven Years .

1999.
JAMES BENNETT
was indicted for
stealing, on the 2d of September , 12lbs. of candles, value 6s., the goods of
Thomas Birke
, his master .
Mr. LAW conducted the prosecution.

JOHN FARRELL
. I am servant to Thomas Birke, a tallowchandler - the prisoner was in his employ. On the 2d of September, about a quarter past nine o'clock at night, I saw him take an apron full of candles out of a box, and take them to his own premises - I gave information to Bain, the foreman, and he was afterwards apprehended - he had 12lbs. or perhaps 18lbs.; he took them from a place where candles are laid out for the men, who work at night; I was in the melting-house; he took a candle to take them.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. How long after this was he in Mr. Birke's employ? A. Eight or ten days - Bain said, "Why did not you stop him" - I said I could not; he said, "Let it lay, and we will catch him again;" he was taken to the office on the 14th and discharged, because I was not there - he did not give himself up on this charge.
COURT. Q. How far was his house off? A. Not twenty yards - I went up-stairs and told Bain directly.

JOHN BAIN
. Farrell informed me of this; I told him to he quiet about it - the prisoner did not surrender himself - I went to his house and found 6lbs. or 8lbs. of candles on the 14th - they were such as we make.

Cross-examined. Q. Why did not you go insantly and search his house? A. I had no authority; I believe there has been a charge against my master for smuggling, but not against me - I have no idea of the prisoner being a witness against my master; I do not expect it - the prisoner is married, and has one child.

RICHARD CORFF
. I apprehended the prisoner on the 14th of September, on a charge of stealing soap - I went to his house, and found a quantity of candles in a box, they were so broken, I have not brought them - he was discharged about the soap; I took him afterwards about the candles.
Cross-examined. Q. Did he give himself up? A. He would, I believe - he sent me word that he would give himself up, but he had been absent.

Prisoner. I never took a candle; the officer let me remain at home all night, on promising to come in the morning, which I did - all the candles I had, these men gave me - Bain has called me up twice to work after the Excise officer came round.

COURT to
JOHN BAIN
. Q. Where does Mr. Birke live? A. In Fulham-road, about three-hundred yards froca the premises; I thought it not worth while to go and tell him; he was at home - I told his son of it - the prisoner never bought any candles; the men are not allowed candles - they were broken candles for the men's use.
NOT GUILTY .

2000.
JAMES BENNETT
was again indicted for
stealing, on the 14th of September , 6lbs. of soap, value 8s. , the goods of
Thomas Birke
.

JOHN BAIN
. On the 8th of September I was in the factory, and heard a noise in the loft - no one has any business there; I had shut it an hour before; I called out,"Who is there?" but received no answer - I ran up-stairs, and met the prisoner coming out, with a box lid in his hand - I said, "What do you want? why not take a light?" he said, "A box-lid, to cover a box;" I looked round, and under a box saw two cakes of soap, in another box - I locked up the place, and when Mr. Birke came in the morning I told him; I then put a crooked nail into the soap, and left it there - it had been moved from the cutting-room. On the 14th it was missed, and I went with the officer to the prisoner's house, and saw him find two cakes of soap in his bureau - on cutting it the crooked nail was in it; I told the officer about the nail.

Cross-examined. Q. Did you state all this to Mr. White, the Magistrate? A. Yes, and he was discharged, because the witness was not there; he was committed by Mr. Hall, at Bow-street. I am not in the habit of calling at his house; Farrell used to call him up in the morning.

RICHARD CORFF
. I apprehended the prisoner - he said he had no soap, and knew nothing of it; I found it in the bureau in his room, and the nail was in it; Bain had said he had put one into it - the bureau was not locked.

Prisoner's Defence. A box of fat stood in the yard; the carpenter sent me for a box lid - I went for it in the dark; the doors were open. Bain called out, "Who is there?" I said, "Me;" the soap had been there for months - Mr. Birke said he had lost none.
RICHARD CORFF. Mr. Birke said he would not swear to it, but left it to Bain.
GUILTY . Aged 25.
Confined Three Months .
Before Mr. Sergeant Arabin.

2001.
WILLIAM POWELL
,
RICHARD EDWARDS
, and
JOHN HARRIS, alias WALKER
, were indicted for
stealing, on the 6th of October , 1 comb, value 1s. 10d. , the goods of
George Hicks
.

GEORGE WADDINGTON
. I am a constable of Bow-street. On the 6th of October, about six o'clock in the evening, I saw Harris at the corner of Liquorpond-street - I stopped in a door-way, and saw the other prisoners come up to him; they stopped under the alms-houses, and talked together, then went on to the corner of Elm-street, and stopped at a grocer's-shop, and bought a basket for 3d.: they came out; Edwards had the basket in his hand - they went on to an oil-shop - Powell and Edwards went in, and Harris staid at the door; they came out, and went on to Mr. Hicks' shop, a turner, in Gray's Inn-lane-road
; Powell and Edwards went in, and were there some time, and Harris went in to them; I went up, and saw Powell with a rule and comb in his hand, standing by a glass-case, with Edwards. Harris was at the end of the counter; they came out across the way, and went a little distance - I crossed over, and pushed Edwards and Powell into a shop, at the corner of Henry-street - Mills brought in Harris, and I found this comb on him - also some stamps, and two wafer-stamps.

RICHARD MILLS
. I was with Waddington - his account is correct.

MARY DICKINS
. I am shopwoman to Mr. George Hicks. Powell and Edwards came in, and asked for a comb for graining, and said it must be three inches and a half long; I showed them some, but none would do; in about seven minutes, while they were there, Harris came in, and said he wanted a brush for graining; I went to look for some, but not finding them readily, he said he would call in the morning, between nine and ten o'clock - he did not appear to know the others; they all went out; Powell had a rule, and measured the comb. In a quarter of an hour the officer came in - I then missed a comb. They had taken up several in the shop, and I missed one then.
Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. Had you counted them before? A. No; we sell a good many such. I believe this to be the one I missed.

ANN HICKS
. I live with my father. I was out at the time, but this comb has my writing on it.
Cross-examined. Q. Are all your combs marked so? A. Yes - if it was sold the ink would still be there.
POWELL'S Defence. I went to buy a comb - they had none: I took nothing.

POWELL -
GUILTY . Aged 20.

EDWARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 38.

HARRIS -
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Transported for Seven Years .

2002.
JOHN GAWTHORNE
and
JOHN SMITH
were indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of October , 7 pieces of leather, value 1l. 15s. , the goods of
George Waite
.

CHARLES HERDSFIELD
. I am an officer. On the 7th of October, between-nine and ten o'clock, I was in Whitecross-street; I saw the two prisoners together - Gawthorne said to Smith, "To-morrow, mind; ten o'clock;" I said to Gawthorne, "What have you got there?" he said,"Some leather" - I asked him where he got it; he said, from Mr. Allen, of Green-arbour-court, Old Bailey, and that Mr. Armstrong had given him 30s. to fetch it and pay for it - I said, "You are not fetching it for yourself;" he said, No. I brought him to Giltspur-street.

DANIEL FORRESTER
. I was with Herdsfield, and took Smith.

JOHN GOODWIN
. I am in the employ of Mr. George Waite, a currier, of No. 16, Gray's-inn-lane. This is the same leather I saw at the examination, but I have seen so many pieces, I should not like to swear to them - I did swear to this piece, but there is no mark upon it; there was a piece of cordovan missing like this, but all shoulders are alike; I said this piece was my master's property, but I had no more reason for knowing it then than I have now - I have seen so many pieces like it since, that it makes me doubtful. Here is a mark on those other six pieces; I have no doubt but they were my master's; but the same person who marked these works for other shops.

COURT. Q. You say in your deposition, "One of these seven pieces of leather, being a neck of cordovan, I saw on my master's premises, and I know it to be his property, and form the marks on the other pieces, I believe them to be his property" - what is your belief now? A. I believe it is.

Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. You have stated that you swore to one piece of leather; is there your master's mark on it? A. No, my master never marks leather - here is the tanner's mark on it; there was a finger-mark on this piece which I swore to, but it is not here now - I only believe them to be his, and cannot say they have not been sold.

GEORGE WAITE
. I believe these seven pieces of leather to be mine; I have no doubt of it - I cannot say I never sold them, but I believe not. The prisoner was my apprentice, and had access to it (looking at his deposition) - I swore positively to them before the Magistrate, as that was my impression; there are marks on it made by a person who is now dead.
NOT GUILTY .

2003.
THOMAS EDWARDS
and
JOSEPH NORRIS
were indicted for
stealing, on the 23d of September , one 5l. note, the property of
Mary Edwards
, from her person .

MARY EDWARDS. I live in Fashion-court, Spitafields. On the 23d of September my daughter gave me a 5l. note to redeem some pledges - I went to the Golden Anchor public-house, Golden-lane
, for change, as the pawnbroker had none - Mrs. Jones, the landlady, returned me the note, as she had no change; I went away with it, and returned again soon after, and held it up for change at the bar, when some person behind me twisted it out of my hand - I was frightened, and cannot swear to any one - it was the same note my daughter had given me.

MARGARET TOMLINSON
. I gave Edwards, who is my mother, a 5l. note, which my brother had given me - it was a new note - he had been paid off the day before; I have not seen it since.

SOPHIA FORDHAM
. I live in Golden-lane. I was at the Golden Anchor on an errand, and saw the prosecutrix come for change for a 5l. note - she held it up in her hand - Norris went behind her, and snatched it out of her hand - Edwards was close behind him; they both ran away together; I am certain of their persons; I knew them both well before, and have no doubt whatever of them - I ran after them, but they got out of my sight - I did not call Stop thief! as I thought I should catch them, and knew I should know them; I knew their names - they have lived in the neighbourhood a long time - I told my father their names directly I got home.

MARGARET JONES
. I keep the public-house. Edwards came on the 23d of September for change for a 5l. note; I could not get it as it was up-stairs, and I had no one to mind the bar; she went out, and came in again, and two or three customers came in at the same time; she held the note up with her finger and thumb, and a bit of the note out; she was standing with her back to the door, and a person, in a light coloured jacket, came in, and snatched it out of her hand; but it was neither of the two prisoners; I do not know the man who took it, but it was neither of them - I did not see Sophia Fordham there - I have a strong suspicion who it was - I saw him walking from the door; there were not two of them; there was only one - I do not know whether Fordham was there - I did not see any girl run out and give an alarm; the first thought that struck me was, that it was her son who took it; I have seen the two prisoners before - they have beenat my house - Fordham lives in the neighbourhood; her father is an officer; I believe the prisoners lived in the neighbourhood - I am not acquainted with their friends - I did not tell the Magistrate that I had some suspicion of a person; but I have seen a chap since brought up for some offence; I do not know what, and have now some suspicion of a person.
COURT. Q. How was the man dressed? A. He had a light coloured coat on; I have called it a jacket - I did not notice which it was.

SOPHIA FORDHAM
re-examined. Q. How were they dressed? A. Norris had corded breeches and a corded jacket, of a dark colour - Edward had a kind of sailor's shirt, a light coloured jacket, and a cap - my father and Harrison took the prisoners - I was close to them; I swear positively they are the men, they were close together.

JAMES MASON
. I am a publician. I changed a 5l. note on the 23d of October, but it was not to either of the prisoners.

JAMES FORDHAM
. I am an officer. I apprehended Norris that evening from my daughter's information - she described him - I have known him for years. I took Edwards about twelve o'clock next day; he had a blue coat on. Norris was in a corderoy jacket and trowsers; we took him to the watch-house; he was talking to some woman there, and said there had been a to-do about a 5l. note at the bottom of Golden-lane. I know they frequented the Golden Anchor public-house all day long, and have moved them from there a hundred times - Edwards had changed his jacket for a coat.

THOMAS HARRISON
. I was with Fordham, and took Norris - Edwards was taken next morning; he had a blue coat on; I had seen Norris at the Golden Anchor scores of times; Edwards had changed his light coat for a blue one with a man named Bone.

NORRIS' Defence. I was at the house having a pint of beer; Fordham came in; I said to Mrs. Jones, "What does he say?" he said there was a 5l. note lost; "Is there?" said I, but no one took me; as I returned from the play, Harrison dragged me into the watch-house.

EDWARD'S Defence. I was at the corner of my own court; one Bone came and said, "Will you sell me your coat;" I said, No - he said, "Let me try it one;" he did, and then went into a public-house to light his pipe - he came out with a 5l. note in his hand, and said, "I have a 5l. note;" he ran against me, and ran away, leaving me his coat to put on.

EDWARDS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.

NORRIS -
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Transported for Seven Years .

2004.
CHRISTOPHER GUDGEON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 26th of September , 1 pair of oars, value 6s. , the goods of
George Leonard
.

GEORGE LEONARD. I am a boat-builder , and live at Poplar
. On the 26th of September I lost a pair of oars out of my shed, which was locked; I had placed them there about one o'clock, and, at a half-past seven, when I left work. I saw the prisoner and another about two hundred yards off, with them on their shoulders; I looked at the mark - they threw them down, and ran away; I pursued, and took the prisoner - they must have got over my wall.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. A man asked if I could row - I said, Yes, and he fetched the oars, but where from I do not know.
GUILTY . Aged 22.
Transported for Seven Years .

2005.
RICHARD JACKSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 13th of September , 2 planes, value 7s., and 1 saw, value 2s., the goods of
George Kitchener
; 2 saws, value 14s.; 2 planes, value 5s.; 1 axe, value 3s.; 1 square, value 1s.; 1 bevil, value 1s.; 2 gimblets, value 8d.; 1 basket, value 1s.; 2 centre-bits, value 1s., and 1 chalkline, value 1s., the goods of
Thomas Newberry
; 1 saw, value 4s.; 1 plane, value 3s., and 1 square, value 1s. , the goods of
James Barnett
.

GEORGE KITCHENER. I am a carpenter and joiner . I left these tools safe, at half-past five o'clock on the night of the 13th of September, in a hoard by the Duke of York's premises, in the Green-park
, and missed them next morning - I believe the shed was locked. The prisoner was a stranger.

EDWARD HEDDINGTON
. I am a constable. On the 14th of September I saw Kitchener in Lawrence's shop, New-cut, Lambeth, where he identified a plane; I went into the back parlour, and found a basket containing the tools in the indictment, among others. I found the prisoner in custody of a patrol. I returned to the shop with a warrant, and found some more property.

THOMAS NEWBERRY
. I am a carpenter . Some of these tools are mine.

THOMAS TRIBE
. I am a carpenter, and work at the Duke of York's house. On the morning of the 14th of September I went to the Rose and Crown public-house; Kitchener said he had lost his tools; I went to the Newcut with him - he found some of his tools at Lawrence's; I saw Redman with some tools in his hand, offering them for sale; Kitchener's name was on them; he took me to the prisoner, at the Three Compasses public-house; McKear, the officer, was fetched, and found thirteen duplicates of tools on him.

JAMES McKEAR
. I am an officer. I took the prisoner, and found thirteen duplicates on him - one of which relates to this property - I found a small tool on him; I asked his name - he said, they called him anything, and he lived anywhere.

WILLIAM BENJAMIN JONES
. I live with Mr. Wells, apawnbroker, Broad-street, Bloomsbury - I have two saws, which I saw the prisoner pawn at our shop, on the 13th of September, between six and seven o'clock - I am positive he is the man.

WILLIAM REDMAN
. I am a carpenter, and live on Walworth-common - I was coming along the New-cut, and saw the prisoner with a basket of tools on his back, and said, "Shopmate, can you tell me of a job?" I had not seen him before, but he looked like a carpenter; he said, No, but he would give me a pint of beer; we went to get a pint of beer; he said, he was going to his brother's, at Charing-cross - I said, I would go with him, as I was going to Maddox-street; we got talking, and on theroad; he said, he would sell the tools as he had got a ship- I said, Laurence over the way bought them, but he had better not sell them; he said, Yes; he had some rent to make up - I went over with them to Laurence, who offered 6s. 6d. - the prisoner came over; he gave him three half-crowns, and he gave him 1s. - he said his name was Smith, and that he lived with his brother, who kept the Shades public-house, at Charling-cross - we went out to the public-house, at Charing-cross - we went out to the public-house, had some bread and cheese, and he asked me to sell two planes for him - I took them openly in my hand, and Tribe stopped me - I took him to the prisoner.(Property produced and sworn to.)
Prisoner's Defence. I did not know they were stolen.
GUILTY . Aged 28.
Transported for Seven Years .

2006.
JACOB EVANS
was indicted for
feloniously killing and slaying
Camp Collins
, by administering to him 6ozs. of decoction of fox-glove, well knowing the same to be a deadly poison .

JOHN BURBIDGE
. I am a cabinet-maker, and live in Bayne's-row, Clerkenwell - Camp Collins was my apprentice ; he died last Thursday morning, about half-past ten o'clock; he was seventeen years old; he had been ailing at intervals for some months; he complained for weeks together of a giddiness in his head, which at times seized him suddenly when at work - he was unable to work for three or four weeks - I have known the prisoner about three years, and I believe he was lately been out of employ - he published a book on the use of herbs some months ago - he called on me last Tuesday, about eleven o'clock, and told me Collins' mother had spoken to him, to know if he could prepare anything from herbs, to prevent this disorder, and he had promised to call and see the boy, and asked how he was afficted - the boy replied, "I feel pretty well now;" "He said, how do you feel when the disease attacks you?" he said, "I am taken with a stupid giddiness, and swimming my head, as if something was running all about me;" the prisoner passed, and then said, "If your mother will get two or three pennyworth of fox-glove at the herbalist, and put to that one quart of water, and boil it till it is reduced to something more than half a pint" - I said, "Mr. Evans, is it to be between half a pint and a pint?" he said Yes - this the boy I believe perfectly understood; the prisoner said, "And then, my boy, you will take half that quantity; it will make you very sick, and work you upwards and downwards" - that he would be in that way for for several hours, and probably not able to work all day - I went down-stairs with the prisoner; and the boy followed us, and said, "Sir, if you have no objection, I had rather Mr. Evans get these things himself, as I do not know where to get them, and my mother will satisfy him;" Evans said, "Very well, the expense will be very few pence;" he then went away, and called again next day (Wednesday) about eleven o'clock - he came into the shop, and said, "Now, my boy, I have brought the stuff, I should like you to take it in something large enough to hold half of it" - the boy fetched up a large breakfast cup, which held something less than half a pint - Evans filled it about three parts full, and said, "Now, my boy, you must not sip this, it is bitter and nasty, you must drink it off at once;" the boy took it from him, and drank it off at a draught - he had some bread and cheese, which he was eating for a lunch, and he eat some very hastily to take the laste out - Evans said, "If this does not operate in about half an hour, take about the same quantity again;" and he said,"You will see, Mr. Burbidge, that he takes it, if it does not begin to operate about that time;" I looked at the watch which hung up, and said, "It is now such a time, and at such a time, the other must be administered;" Evans had not left the shop till the half hour expired - the boy then untied his apron, began to rub himself, and then went down to the yard; he returned in a short time - Evans had then left the shop; the boy continued to work for about a quarter of an hour or twenty minutes - I conceived the stuff had taken its effect, and did not give him the second dose - the boy then complained of being very sick, and went into the next room, which was his bed-room, and vomitted a good deal - I went to him in about ten minutes, and said, "Can you come down to dinner?" he said, "I fear, I cannot eat I am so sick;" he came down, saw the dinner, but went up directly, saying he was so sick. When I returned from dinner, I asked how he was? he said, "Very sick" - he had then taken the medicine and hour and a half - he took it exactly at ten minutes to twelve o'clock, and it was twenty minutes past when he went into the yard - he still complained of being very sick, but brought very little up, except some green yellow stuff - I went to him several times, found him very sick, and advised him to walk about, as it would operate better - at four o'clock, I asked him down to tea; he said he had rather have it sent up - it was sent up; he took some, but eat nothing - a little before five o'clock, he came down into the kitchen, drew a chair to the fire, and leaned his head on the table, and at short intervals vomited - my wife advised him to take some warm water, which he declined; I said I thought he had better take the other half, but he did not. I came down about seven o'clock, and thought he was asleep; I said to my wife he had better not sleep there; he said,"I am not asleep, I had rather sit by the fire, as I feel so sick" - I then went out and found his parents at a chapel, told them of it, and said I thought he had not taken sufficient; they advised me to persuade him to take the rest; I went home and found my wife had just put him to bed; she went up to him a little before ten o'clock, he appeared asleep, and she brought the light down - a man named Harris went up about a quarter to eleven, and he thought him asleep; he slept in the next bed - I went up about ten minutes to seven o'clock in the morning, and he said he was very sick every now and then, but in no pain except in his head, putting his hand to his forehead - I sent for Mr. Whitmore, and about half-past ten o'clock the boy died. He was opened next morning, in my presence - there were four surgeons. The prisoner had never said how much the two or three pennyworth of fox-glove would produce - the bottle was about three-parts full; he did not give him quite half; here is the bottle, with the remainder of the stuff in it.

MR.
HENRY WHITMORE
. I am a surgeon, and live in Coldbath-square - I have been practising for seventeen or eighteen years. I was called in about half-past seven o'clock last Thursday morning, and found the boy labouring under symptoms common to vegetable nancatle poison, and under some symptoms peculiar to a preparation of fox-glove - his pulse was slow, weak, and very irregular; his extremities cold, and the pupil of the eye ceased to obey the rays of light - I had the room darkened, called for a candle, and found the pupil would not contract and dilate. I was told he had taken fox-glove, and the symptoms agreed with that; they could not have deceived me if they had tried, as he had taken such an immense quantity - I ordered him braudy every ten minutes, gave him medicine, and ordered him blisters; but he died while they were preparing. I afterwards opened his body, and there was an absence of all disease that might have produced death. Death is produced by vegetable poison, not by occasioning disease, but by lessening the energy of the nervous system, so that the heart and all the energies cease to act. I have no doubt the decoction of fox-glove caused his death; it is a medicine which is admiaistered in similar cases. The boy had been under my care for two months, and I had repeatedly administered it to him, properly guarded; it was a case in which I judged it right - I administered it to him successfully, I think, as his health was restored, and he returned to work. I cannot say how much would be sold for 2d. or 3d.; the prisoner told me, in the Coroner's Jury-room, that he had boiled down 4 ozs., which was a greater quantity than I thought - from measuring the cup, the boy must have taken about 51/2 ozs. of the stuff, as 61/2 ozs. are left in the bottle, which makes 12 ozs., which 4 ozs. would produce. It is impossible such a quantity could be given without danger; from calculation, I find the quantity of decoction twenty-four times the strength our College orders us to make, and then he had given him six times the quantity beyond our extreme dose, and twelve or fifteen times the quantity beyond the common dose. Nothing but complete ignorance could have led to such a dose being given - in my opinion, it must have produced death - I should have thought five or seven drops of this mixture a proper dose. I have seen the book the prisoner has published, and am sorry to say, it will produce much mischief, if acted upon. I remember a case where an undue and uncertain quantity of fox-glove was given, and was unexpectedly beneficial, but I do not know how much.
NOT GUILTY .

2007.
JOHN TIFF
was indicted for
killing and slaying
Daniel Baker
,
MR. ALLEY conducted the prosecution.

WILLIAM SNOW
. I am a waterman. On the 30th of September I had brought a lady from a ship, with a quantity of luggage - she was landing at Blackwall-stairs
; the prisoner was there, acting as a porter ; Baker came up, and said to the lady, "Do you want me, ma'am;" she said to me, "Yes; give the chest and hammock to that tall man;" he came to the boat, took hold of the rope, and the prisoner struck him the first blow - they put themselves in a fighting attitude - Baker fell on the gunwale of a boat, in the third round - I heard him say, Oh! but they fought two more rounds afterwards, and Baker died in about twenty minutes.

WILLIAM JONES PERCEVAL
. I am a surgeon. I was fetched to the deceased, and found him dying - after his death I opened his body, and found five or six pints of extravasated blood in the belly; there were several external bruises, and one corresponding with the rupture of the spleen - he died from the extravasation of blood occasioned by that rupture - the spine had been diseased before.
Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Would his fighting occasion it? A. Not without receiving a blow.

JAMES LEWIS
. I saw this man after his death - the surgeon saw the same person.
Cross-examined. Q. Were you present when he examined it? A. No; he was carried to the King's Arms public-house, and laid on the table; there was no other dead man there - I did not search the house.

Prisoner's Defence (written). I called out to know if the lady wanted a porter to carry the things on shore; Daniel Baker also plied her; she nodded, and on the boat reaching the shore the waterman called to me, to pull her in, which I did. I then took hold of the hammock, which the deceased perceiving, attempted to take from me; and in so doing, he pushed me into the water. I got out of the water, and, in the irritation of the moment, struck him, which was returned, and we fought four or five rounds. He being older than myself, I rather endeavoured to keep him off, than to strike him; but in the last round he unfortunately fell on the nose of the boat, which hurt the spine and caused his death. I had no animosity whatever towards the deceased: indeed I hardly knew him.
GUILTY . Aged 18.
Confined Two Months .

2008.
MARTHA BYATT
was indicted for
that she, on the 30th of September , at St. George, Hanover-square, 12 pieces of false and counterfeit milled money and coin, each and every of them made and counterfeited to the likeness and similitude of a piece of good, lawful, and current milled money and silver coin of the realm, called a shilling; the same counterfeited and milled money, nor either of them not being then cut in pieces, unlawfully and feloniously did put off to one George Dutton at a lower rate and value than they by their denomination did import and were counterfeited for, that is to say, for the sum of 4s., against the statute .

2d COUNT, the same, only stating that the said counterfeited pieces of milled money were put off at a lower rate, &c. that is to say, for four pieces of the current coin of this realm, called shillings, of the value of 1s. each, against the statute.
MR. BOLLAND conducted the prosecution.

GEORGE DUTTON
. I have known the prisoner from my childhood - eighteen years - in consequence of a communication from Limbrick, I had some interview with her, and agreed for her to meet me, on the 30th of September, at the Green Man public-house, Green-street, Grosvenor-square - she came - I saw her three or four doors from the house - I went in, and asked for a glass of cold gin and water - I then saw her come up to the house, and told Limbrick she was at the door; Lee then searched me in Limbrick's presence; I had nothing about me; Lee then gave me four shillings, which Limbrick marked - I put them into my pocket; I went to the prisoner, and asked if she had any little ones, meaning sixpences - I then said I wanted two dozen big ones, meaning shillings - she said, "You aregoing to break me at once" - I said, "No; I mean one dozen of big ones;" which she gave me; I put them into my pocket, and gave her the four shillings, which I had in my pocket - I went in, and in a few minutes, she was brought into the parlour and searched; I was also searched.
Prisoner. Q. Did I agreed to meet you that night? A. Your daughter did; you had agreed to meet me on the 25th of September, but did not come; and your daughter agreed for you to meet me on the 30th.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I am an officer of Hatton-garden. In consequence of information, which I received about the prisoner, I gave directions to Dutton; Lee and Kirby were in company with me. On the 30th of September, about a quarter to nine o'clock at night, at the Green Man; Dutton came into the house, and said, "They are in sight" - Lee then searched him - he had nothing about him; Lee gave him four shillings, which I had marked - he went out, and soon after returned. saying, "It is all right;" I then saw the prisoner brought in - she was searched, and the four marked shillings, which had been given to Dutton, were found on her - I searched Dutton, and found these twelve counterfeit shillings on him (producing them) - he said in her presence, that he got them from her; she exclaimed, "Oh! you traitor! Oh! Mr. Limbrick, I am a dead woman."

WILLIAM LEE
. I was with Limbrick on this evening; he gave me four marked shillings, which I gave Dutton, after seeing that he had nothing about him - I went out shortly after him, and saw the prisoner near him - I took her, brought her in, and I found on her the four shillings, which I had given to Dutton; twelve shillings were found on him.

WILLIAM KIRBY
. I have heard the officer's evidence - it is correct.

JOSEPH NICHOL
. I am moneyer of the Mint. These shillings are counterfeit, and from one die - they do not appear to have been in circulation, but they have been prepared for circulation.

JOHN FIELD
. I am an inspector of counterfeit coin. - The shillings are counterfeit - they have been rubbed down with scowering-paper, and then coloured with something, to make them look black, as if they had been in circulation.

Prisoner's Defence. I have had twelve children - my husband is a painter and glazier, but neglected his business; I have been left in distress, and for a week together have been without a bit of meat; I have been brought to this through a person who owed me some rent, and gave me seven score of these - I kept them by me a long time, and wanted bread while I had them. I have often returned, after going out to pass them, and pawned something instead; it was nothing but distress led me to do it.
GUILTY .

The prisoner was called upon to receive judgment, and upon praying benefit of clergy, a counter-plea was put in, on behalf of the Crown, and a record of the conviction of
Martha Byatt
read, for having put off, on the 25th of February, 1819, seven counterfeit shillings, to Cecilia Willis, for 2s. 71/2d. - the prisoner pleaded that she was not the same person, upon which a Jury were impannelled to try the issue.

CALEB EDWARD POWELL
. I am assistant to the solicitor of the Mint. I produce a copy of the record of the conviction of Martha Byatt, at the April Session, 1819; I examined it with the original - it is correct - (read).

BARNARD GLEED
. I am an officer. I know the prisoner, and knew her in 1819 - I was present at the April Session that year; the prisoner is the person who was tried and convicted here - I was a witness on that occasion, and gave evidence against her.

GEORGE BRAND
. I was a turnkey at the House of Correction in 1819; the prisoner was in my custody twelve months from that time - I am certain of her person.
The Jury found that she was the same person, and she accordingly received sentence of Death .

2009.
ELIZA BYATT
was indicted for
a like offence, in putting off, on the 27th of September , six counterfeit shillings; and the said
MARTHA BYATT
was indicted for that she, before the said felony was committed, unlawfully did counsel, aid, abet, and procure the said Eliza Byatt, to do and commit the said felony, in manner and form aforesaid, against the statute .

GEORGE DUTTON
. I had seen Martha Byatt on the 25th of September, and agreed to meet her on the 27th, at a person's house, near North-row; she promised she would have some little ones - I went to the place, but she was not there; the prisoner came in the evening, and sent for me; I went out, found her in Green-street, and said, "Have you got any little ones?" she said, No, but she had got six big ones, meaning counterfeit shillings, which I took of her, and gave her two goods shillings, which Limbrick had given to me, on the Tuesday before - I kept the bad shillings till I saw Limbrick, and gave them to him.
Prisoner ELIZA BYATT. Q. Did I say I came from my mother? A. Yes; she did not say she brought them on her own account.

JOHN LIMBRICK
. I am an officer. In consequence of information I gave directions to Dutton, and gave him two shillings, which were not marked; I afterwards received from him six counterfeit shillings, which I produce - they were wrapped in paper, as they are now; Kirby was with me when I apprehended Eliza.

JOHN FIELD
. These are counterfeit shillings, and have never been in circulation.
ELIZA BYATT's Defence. My mother never brought me to this - it is I that has brought her to it.
NOT GUILTY .

2010.
JOHN PARKINSON
was indicted for
stealing, on the 25th of October , 1 hammer, value 1s. 6d., and 1 trowell, value 2s. , the goods of
Samuel Dade
.

SAMUEL DADE. I am a plasterer , and was working at a house in Tavistock-square
. I was on the scaffold, heard somebody coming up-stairs, and saw the prisoner go into the parlour, take up these tools, and put them into his pocket; I went and met him at the top of the areasteps - he pleaded distress.

ANDREW ROBINS
. I am an officer, and took him in charge.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 50.
Confined Two Months .

2011.
GEORGE ROCK
was indicted for
stealing, onthe 3d of October , 3 handkerchiefs, value 15s. , the goods of
John Roose
.

JOHN ROOSE. I keep a linen-draper's-shop , in Commercial-terrace, Commercial-road
. My daughter alarmed me, and I found the prisoner in custody with these handkerchiefs.

MICHAEL SMITH
. I live with Mr. Roose. The prisoner came in, and asked for some hooks and eyes, which I showed him: he said they were not stout enough - and as I turned to put them away, I saw him take the handkerchiefs and put them under his coat; he ran away, and I after him - he was taken with them in about three minutes.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY . Aged 17.
Confined Three Months .

2012.
CHARLES SIMMS
was indicted for
stealing, on 5th of October , 8 lamp-irons, value 5s. , the goods of the
Trustees of St. Matthew, Bethnal-green
.
The property in question being affixed to the houses, and the prisoner not being indicted under that statute, he was
ACQUITTED .

2013.
WILLIAM JENKINS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of September , 3lbs. of sugar, value 3s., and 2lbs. of butter, value 2s., the goods of
Cornelius Wright
and
William Wright
, his masters .

WILLIAM WRIGHT. I am a confectioner
, in partnership with my father, Cornelius Wright. The prisoner was employed to make biscuits . On the evening of the 27th of September, the errand-boy called me from tea - I came down, and sent a man after the prisoner, who brought him back and Coombs took this sugar from him - he said he was going to take it home; I found 2lbs. of sugar in his hat, and the butter in a bag.

HENRY COOMBS
. I am porter to the prosecutors. I saw the prisoner brought back, and took the sugar out of his hat - he said he had nothing there.

THOMAS BARTLETT
. I took him in charge.
GUILTY. Aged 16.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Fourteen Days .

2014.
GEORGE BRIGGS
was indicted for
stealing, on the 8th of October , 1 handkerchief, value 2s., the goods of a certain man, whose name is unknown, from his person .

ANGELIUS BERTRAUN
. I am an officer. On the 8th of October I stood at the corner of Oxford-street
, and saw the prisoner and another person cross from St. Giles', after two gentlemen; I saw the prisoner take a gentleman's handkerchief, and run from him; I stopped him, and knocked off his cap - he turned into Dudley-court; I saw a door open; I found him up in a garret under a table - he had not got the handkerchief then.

ELIZABETH HALL
. I was at breakfast - the prisoner ran into my room, and said some one was going to beat him - the officer came in and took him.
GUILTY . Aged 16.

Confined Three Months and
Whipped .

2015.
MARIA TITCOMBE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 27th of October , 2 gowns, value 1s.; 1 napkin, value 6d.; 3 gown bodies, value 3s., and 1 wrapper, value 6d., the goods of
John Hassall Glanham
, her master .

ELIZABETH GLANHAM
. I am the wife of John Hassall Glanham, a grocer , who lives in Earl-street
. The prisoner was eighteen months in my service; I missed these articles after she left me; I went with a warrant, and found them where she went to live.

THOMAS CLEMENTS
. I am an officer. I went with a warrant to No. 22, Leonard-street, and found this property in a box which the prisoner unlocked, and said it was her's.(Property produced and sworn to.)
GUILTY. Aged 20.

Recommended to Mercy . -
Confined Three Months .
Third Middlesex Jury - Before Mr. Common Sergeant.

2016.
JOHN JONES
was indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 1 carpet, value 8s. , the goods of
Lyana Mesure
.

JOHN JENNER
. I am servant to Lyana Mesure, auctioneer , of Holborn. I saw the prisoner come into the shop on the 29th of September, about eight o'clock in the morning, and take this carpet, and go out with it; I followed, took it from him, about four doors off, and sent Walker after him - we overtook him - I am certain of his person.

JAMES WALKER
. I live at Mr. Mesure's. I was coming down-stairs - a man called me - I ran out, and Jenner recognised the prisoner in Drury-lane; I brought him back - he denied it - Jenner said he took it from his arm.
Prisoner's Defence. I had not had the carpet.
GUILTY . Aged 21.
Confined Three Months .

2017.
THOMAS SKINNER
,
WILLIAM MORRIS
,
ELIZABETH GASCOWEN
, and
MARY BODEN
were indicted for
stealing, on the 29th of September , 1 trunk, value 6s.; 20 table-cloths, value 15l. 10s. 6d.; 20 pillow-cases, value 3l. 10s.; 6 bolster-cases, value 1l. 4s.; 30 towels, value 2l. 5s.; 9 cloths, value 2l.; 2 pieces of linen, value 9s.; 10 yards of dimity, value 10s.; 5 yards of cotton, value 10s.; 2 coverlids, value 6s.; 1 shawl, value 5s., and 4 napkins, value 14s. ; the goods of
William Bowie
.

ELIZABETH BOWIE
. I am the wife of William Bowie. On Friday the 29th of September we removed from Burr-street to Crombie-row, Mile-end Old-town; I had a trunk containing the articles stated in the indictment; I saw it put into the van a little before seven o'clock at night - here is a table-cloth and towel, which I can swear to.

Cross-examined by MR. PHILLIPS. Q. Have you any mark upon them? A. My husband is a table-linen manufacturer - it is our own manufacture, and was the only one that was in the trunk of this pattern; I washed it the day before I put it into the trunk - it was marked E. B., but the the mark is picked out; I have sold a great many of that pattern; I know the napkin by the loop - that is not a general thing; I have seen some so, but few people take the trouble of doing it - here is a hole in one corner, by which I know it.

JOHN HENRY BOWIE
. I am the prosecutor's son. I assisted in removing the goods - Morris had asked me if Iwanted a van; I said, No, I had engaged one; I went again to get it, and when I came back, Morris was there; I had not hired him - we told them to put the trunks first into the van, but this trunk was left to the last - Morris then wanted to put it at the back on the top, but we moved a heavy basket of crockery, and put it under it - they were then in a hurry to get loaded, and I said, I would give them a pot of beer - we passed by a public-house opposite the London-docks - I gave Morris 1s. to get a pot of beer there; I saw several people come out of that house, and pass on - the van then went on to Crombie's-row, which may be a mile or a mile and a half; I took a basket, containing some glasses and light things, and went into the house; I had told Morris not to take anything out till I had seen it was all clear - when I went in, this trunk was in the van, and not a rope was touched, but I cannot say whether the rope was attached to the trunk or not - when I came out, I could not see the trunk - the basket was on the ground - Morris was about the place; I jumped on the van, and, when I had been up about a second, a man said that a man had gone down a turning on the other side of the way with a trunk of ours; I called to some one to run after him - Morris heard me, but he stopped about two minutes, pulling off his jacket; he then ran a little way, but returned in about a minute, and said, "Where is the man that said the trunk was gone?" there was an alarm, and a number of people round the van, so that I was afraid to go away myself; this is the trunk which I missed; I found it the next day at Mr. Dunbar's, a broker; I had observed it on the van, when I left it to go into the house; I know that my father had this pattern of tablecloths about fourteen years ago, and they were sold to Lady Cooke, of Norfolk, and a table-cloth of this pattern has been in use in our family ever since.

EDWARD KING
. I am a carman. I went to Burr-street to remove some goods, as I was going by the toll-gate near the London-docks; I saw Morris talking to the toll-man - he asked if I was going to Burr-street to load some furniture; I said, Yes - he asked if they would want any body to help - I said, I did not know; he said he had nothing to do, and had a great mind to go and see if he could get a job; he went in the van, and assisted to load the goods - this trunk came out last, and I was surprised at it, because I had given orders for the trunks to be placed in the bottom of the van - when we went to Crombie's-row Morris went with us, and he took this trunk out, and placed it on the ground; I asked him why he did not take it into the house; he said, the house was not ready; he then moved it to the side of the cart next the road; I asked him what he wanted with it; he said, To stand on it to reach a rope;" there was a rope that he might have wanted it for; and in a minute or two it was gone.

SARAH TURNER
. I live in Albion-street. I saw Mary Boden bring this trunk with
James Spencer
into Elizabeth Gascowen's room, No. 30, Albion-street, on the evening of the 29th of September - it appeared loaded and heavy; I went into the room, and saw Elizabeth Gascowen light a candle - I went home, and left them there; in about twenty minutes Gascowan and Boden came to me, and Gascowen said there was a box in the alley, and told me to go and take it which I did - this is it; I am sure it is the same that I saw them take into Gascowen's room - when I went out, the lock was off, but it was lying on the top of it; I sold it the next day to Mr. Dunbar - on the Sunday evening, Gascowan offered to give me two napkins, but I would not have them.

JAMES DUNBAR
. I keep a broker's shop. On the 30th of September I went to Albion-street, and bought this trunk of Sarah Turner.

HESTER SOLOMAN
. Mary Boden came to my house, and asked me if I knew any body who wanted to buy half a dozen of table-cloths; I cannot say when it was.

JAMES LEE
. I am an officer of Lambeth-street. I heard of the robbery; I went to Skinner's room, and found a table-cloth and towel - he and Gascowen were in bed together; I took Morris a few days after.

MORRIS' Defence. I went there to get a job - they agreed to give me 2s. 6d. to assist; I did not hear him tell me not to unload; I took the trunk to stand on, and while we were getting a chest of drawers off, the box was taken.

GASCOWEN's Defence. Spencer came up to me, and Boden, with the box, and said, "May I take this into your room till my landlord comes in?" he said it belonged to a sailor - he went out with a bundle; I have not seen him since; I found the table-cloth and napkin on the stairs.
BODEN's Defence. Turner said she would burn the name out, as she knew what Spencer was, and she thought it was not got honestly.

HANNAH BAKER
. I live in Henry-street. Turner came to me, and said, if I would give her a gown and apron, she would not come here.

SARAH TURNER
. It is not true.
NOT GUILTY .

2018.
JOSEPH MOORE
was indicted for
stealing, on the 7th of October , 12 dwts. of gold, value 34s. 6d., the goods of
Francis Carpenter
, his master .

FRANCIS CARPENTER. I am a goldsmith , and live in Clerkenwell
- the prisoner was my apprentice . On the 5th of October I gave him some pieces of platted gold to work up into a chain - he went out that evening, but returned at night, and the next day I received information and sent for an officer; the prisoner was searched in my presence, and I saw a lot of gold found, which weighed about twelve grains; I knew it to be part of what I had given to him - here are two pieces in the same form as I gave them to him.
Cross-examined by MR. CLARKSON. Q. Have you not trusted him with much property? A. Yes; other persons have the same sort of gold - I know one piece in particular by the pattern.

JOHN DAVIS
. I am an officer. I searched the prisoner - he asked where my warrant was - I found this gold in paper in his fob; he said he hoped his master would forgive him, as it was but the second time.

ABRAHAM LEVISON
. I live in Elder-street, Spitalfields, and am a working jeweller. The prisoner ordered me to make him a ring for his finger, on the Saturday before he was taken - he afterwards came in a hurry and asked me to lend him 5s.; I said I had no money - he said he would bring me some gold, if I would buy it - he said hismaster was a Frenchman, but did not say where he lived; he then said he would have the money, and bid me good night - I saw Mr. Carpenter on Tuesday, and gave him information.
Cross-examined. Q. You did not lend him 5s.? A. No.
GUILTY. Aged 15.
The prisoner received a good character, and was Recommended to Mercy .

Confined Six Months , and
Whipped .

2019.
EDWARD JARVIS
was indicted for
bigamy .
MR. ADOLPHUS conducted the prosecution.

JOHN GEORGE LEIGH
. I am deputy parish clerk of St. George, Hanover-square. I have the marriage-register, by which it appears that on the 3d of July last,
Edward Jarvis Tollast
, widower, and
Elizabeth Whitehurst
, spinster , were married - it is witnessed by Hemry and myself - I do not remember the parties.
JOHN HEMRY. I witnessed this marriage - I remember the prisoner as the person married to Miss Elizabeth Whitehurst; she is now in court.

Cross-examined by MR. ANDREWS. Q. Were you a friend of the parties? A. No; I am a publican, and live opposite to the church-gate - Jarvis ordered a breakfast at my house for four or five persons, but only himself and Whiteburst came: after breakfast, he said he was going to be married, and was in a difficulty about nobody coming to be witnesses, and asked if I would go over, which I did; I knew neither of them before - I asked him where the lady lived; he said in Windmill-street. Tottenham-court-road - I have seen her several times since.

HANNAH GREY
. Up to the 10th of August , I was a widow ; on that day I married the prisoner at St. Mary, Lambeth, Surry
.

Cross-examined. Q. Had you known him before? A. Yes, for two or three months; Miss Finlayson is my niece; He parted from me at Kennington about three days after we were married, and I lodged at a butcher's at Camden-town.

JAMES LEDGER
. I apprehended the prisoner on a warrant for an assault, in Church-passage, St. Giles.
GUILTY . Aged 54.

2020.
EDWARD JARVIS
was again indicted for
a like offence .

JOHN GEORGE LEIGH
. I produce the marriage-register of St. George, Hanover-square, by which it appears that Edward Jarvis, bachelor, was married to
Rachael Pearce
, spinster , by license, on the 16th of December, 1797 - I was not in office at that time - the register is signed Thomas Ash, curate, and by the clerk and sexton; I knew their writing - the clerk and sexton are dead.

JOHN STRATTON
. I know the prisoner; he came to work for me about six years ago - he came from Horncastle, in Lincolnshire; he sent for his wife, and she came up; I saw her, and have heard her say her maiden name was Rachael Pearce, many times, in his presence; they lodged in my house; she is now living in Clarendon-street, Somer's-town - she is the same person who lived with him, as his wife - they have a son about twenty-four years old, and a daughter older; they always treated them as their children; his wife is about sixty years old.
Cross-examined. Q. Do you know where she is now? A. Yes; I saw her six weeks ago - he called her Rachael, and also wife, and she called him husband. The children called them mother and father.

ELIZABETH FINLAYSON
. I am niece to Mrs. Gray. I obtained an extract of the register which has been produced. I saw Rachael Jarvis at Clarendon-street - I afterwards saw the prisoner behind the counter of a shop in Windmill-street - I cannot say he was serving there; I told him of his marriage to Rachael Pearce, of Clarendon-street - he at first denied it, but afterwards said she was his wife; I said, "How could you think of marrying my aunt, when you knew you were married?" he said he knew he was a scoundrel or villain, and said, "I know I am married, and my wife is a good manager, a good liver, and a good provider, but our tempers did not agree;" I said, "You have taken my aunt's money?" he said, "Yes, I have;" I said, "Now, take my advice, young as I am - take 100l. and fly." but he would not.

Cross-examined. Q. Was it by your advice your aunt prosecuted? A. Not exactly; I thought it my duty to interfere. I live with my mother. The prisoner and my aunt only lived together four or five days - she asked my advice about this; she is sixty-eight years old, and I am nineteen.

JOHN GEORGE LEIGH
. I produce the register of the prisoner's marriage to Whitehurst, as I read before.

ELIZABETH WHITEHURST
. This register is signed by me; the prisoner is the man I married at St. George, Hanover-square
, on the 3d of July .

Prisoner's Defence. I am compelled to state that Pearce never was my wife, nor was I in London till about five years ago; I never acknowledged to Finlayson that Pearce was my wife - all our conversation was about my running away.
